column6: Introduction to models and listening and their applicability to college lecture situations. Misconceptions, barriers, self-evaluation concepts, memory techniques, and note taking strategies are included.

column2: INTRODUCTION TO COMMUNICATION DISORDERS AND DIFFERENCES
column6: An introduction to communication disorders and differences using a) case studies via film and video review and critique, b) lecture, and c) class discussions. Covers speech, language, swallowing and hearing disorders and cultural and linguistic differences in communication.
Personal improvement course for the development of voice, articulation and pronunciation through study of structures of speech mechanism with intensive drills and practice.
Acoustics, psychoacoustics, bioacoustics, anatomy and physiology of the ear.
Basic principles of speech production and phonetic transcriptions of English with the international phonetic alphabet; emphasis on general American dialect.
Functional anatomy and physiology of the respiratory, phonatory, articulatory and neural systems as they are used in speech production by talkers with normal and abnormal speech.

column4: SPA 34102 or ENG 31001; and special approval.
column6: Normal development and linguistic analysis of language systems including phonology, morphology syntax semantics and pragmatics.

column2: PHONEMIC BASES OF SPEECH AND LANGUAGE
column6: Fundamental processes related to production and perception of spoken language, with parallels to writing and reading particular application to normal and hearing impaired children and adolescents. For non-majors only.
Assessment and remediation of disorders of articulation and phonology.

column2: LANGUAGE DISORDERS IN CHILDREN AND ADOLESCENTS
column6: Introduction to assessment and intervention procedures associated with language disorders in children and adolescents.

column2: COMMUNICATION DISORDERS IN CHILDREN AND ADOLESCENCE
column4: Not open to majors in speech pathology and audiology.
column6: Orientation to etiologies and remediation of communication disorders found in pediatric and adolescent populations.

column4: SPA 33101 and SPA 34102 (speech pathology majors) or SPA 34105 and SPA 43600 (education majors).
column6: Basic principles, variables and techniques for understanding evaluating and improving expressive communication of hearing impaired individuals.

column4: SPA 33101 with minimum C (2.0) grade and special approval.
column6: Measurement of human hearing by pure-tone and speech audiometry; evaluation of middle ear function by immittance audiometry; screening techniques; pathologies of the conductive and sensorineural systems.

column4: SPA 33101 and 34102 and 43402 (Speech Pathology and Audiology majors) or 43600 (Education of Hearing Impaired majors).
column6: Basic principles, variables and techniques for understanding, evaluating and improving receptive communication of hearing impaired individuals.
Lab exercises and practical experiences in audiometric procedures, test interpretation, counseling and management of the hearing impaired.
Readings and discussion of classic and current research on the evaluation of hearing disorders.

Auditory development and function/dysfunction; auditory assessment and family counseling; selection and fitting of personal and classroom amplification; care and maintenance of amplification systems; collaboration of professionals in audiology and education; communication approaches according to varying levels of hearing loss; classroom environments conducive to auditory and academic learning.

column4: Senior standing and speech pathology and audiology (SPA) major and special approval.
column6: Readings and/or research on problems approved by chairman of department in consultation with student's adviser and project director.
Consideration of physiological and acoustic characteristics of normal speech production and perception with implications for speech and hearing disorders.

column4: SPA 34103 or special approval of the instructor.
column6: Anatomy and physiology of the nervous system underlying human neuromotor movements. Topics include: definition and fundamental concepts, afferent and effort systems, cortical anatomy and function, cranial nerves theories of brain function and neural maturation and learning.

Non-pathological age-related changes in speech, language and voice. Topics include structural changes in orofacial, laryngeal and respiratory mechanism; sequelae for speech, language and voice in the elderly; effects of age on swallowing; facilitating conversational interactions with elderly individuals.
Hearing, speech and language disorders in geriatric population. Symptoms, causes and treatment: normal changes in hearing, language and speech accompanying aging process.
Examination of evaluative and therapeutic procedures used with communicatively-impaired children and adults.
Fundamental evaluation and management procedures of individuals with communication disorders, including supervised observation. Corequisite: SPA 44310.
Orientation to types of speech, hearing and language disorders found in Departments and how classroom teachers should handle them. Closed to Speech Pathology and Audiology majors.

column4: Education of hearing impaired majors: SPA 34105 and SPA 43600. Speech pathology and audiology majors: SPA 33101 and SPA 34102. Graduate standing.
column6: Basic principles, variables and techniques for understanding evaluating and improving expressive communication of hearing impaired individuals.

column4: SPA 33101with a grade of C (2.0) or better. Graduate standing.
column6: Measurement of human hearing by pure-tone and speech audiometry; evaluation of middle ear function by immittance audiometry; screening techniques; pathologies of the conductive and sensorineural systems.

column4: Education of Hearing Impaired majors: SPA 43600; Speech Pathology and Audiology majors: SPA 33101 and SPA 34102 and SPA 43402. Graduate standing.
column6: Basic principles, variables and techniques for understanding, evaluating and improving receptive communication of hearing impaired individuals.
Readings and discussion of classic and current research on the evaluation of hearing disorders.
Readings and/or research on problems approved by chair of department in consultation with student's adviser and project director.
Consideration of physiological and acoustic characteristics of normal speech production and perception with implications for speech and hearing disorders.

column2: NEURAL PROCESSES IN SPEECH AND LANGUAGE
column4: SPA 34103 or special approval of the instructor. Graduate standing.
column6: Anatomy and physiology of the nervous system underlying speech and language. Topics include: definition and fundamental concepts, afferent and efferent systems, cortical anatomy and function, cranial nerves, theories of brain function and neural maturation and learning.

Non-pathological age-related changes in speech, language and voice. Topics include: structural changes in orofacial, laryngeal and respiratory mechanisms; sequelae for speech, language and voice in the elderly; effects of age on swallowing; facilitating conversational interactions with elderly individuals.
Hearing, speech and language disorders in geriatric population. Symptoms, causes and treatment: normal changes in hearing, language and speech accompanying aging process.

column4: SPA 34103 or SPA 34106 and graduate standing.
column6: An examination of evaluative and therapeutic procedures used with communicatively impaired children and adults.
Behavioral and physiological assessment of auditory and vestibular site-of-lesion.
Historical through contemporary views of the selection and fitting of amplification for the hearing impaired. Consideration of legal, political and financial issues when choosing to dispense.

column2: ANATOMY AND PHYSIOLOGY OF THE HEARING MECHANISM
column6: Anatomy and physiology of the peripheral and central hearing mechanism, including the embryological development of the ear; some emphasis on conductive and sensorineural pathologies.

Foundations, instrumentation, protocols and interpretation of electrophysiological testing in audiology. Tests include brainstem response audiometry, otoacoustic emissions, electronystagmography and intraoperative monitoring.
Strategies for the selection, fitting and verification of advanced hearing aid technology.
Audiological testing techniques in children including auditory development, philosophy in the selection of a test battery, and pathological conditions affecting the pediatric population.
Generic and specific models for implementing aural rehabilitation programs with children and adults.
Basic principles, theories, methods and findings relating physical and psychological dimensions of sound.

Research, readings and discussion in any of these areas: aural rehabilitation, amplification, psychoacoustics, auditory physiology, medical audiology, hearing conservation. Repeatable up to a maximum of 12 semester hours.
Special topics seminar for advanced students in speech-language pathology and audiology. Presentations and discussion of research projects are required. Repeatable to 9 credits.
Variable topic workshop offered when need arises, either on or off campus to update training in a particular area of speech pathology.
Independent study of topics to be selected in consultation with graduate faculty. May be repeated for maximum of 12 credit hours.
Research or individual investigation for master's level graduate students. Repeated registration permitted.

Reading and discussion seminar on swallowing disorders and the communication disorders relating to aphasia, apraxia, dysarthria, closed head injury, right brain damage and dementia. Repeatable up to 9 hours.
Thesis students must register for a total of 6 hours, 2 to 6 hours in a single semester distributed over several semesters if desired.
Topics are selected for class investigation from the areas of child language development or disorders. Repeatable up to 9 hours.

column4: SPA 64199 and graduate standing and special approval.
column6: Thesis students must continue registration each semester until all degree requirements are met.
Neuro-anatomy, etiologies, symptomatologies, evaluation procedures and treatment techniques relating to aphasia and apraxia of speech in adults.

column2: LANGUAGE ASSESSMENT AND INTERVENTION IN EARLY CHILDHOOD
column6: Methods of language assessment and intervention for infants, toddlers and PreDepartmenters who are either at risk or diagnosed as presenting language delays or disabilities.
Diagnosis and remediation of children's articulation and phonological disorders.

Neuro-anatomy, etiologies, symptomatologies, evaluation procedures and treatment techniques relating to cognitive-communicative disorders in adults subsequent to right brain damage, head trauma and dementia.

column4: peech language pathology (SLP) major and graduate standing.
column6: Nature, theories and their derived therapeutic approaches to the treatment of fluency disorders.
Normal aspects of voice production, etiology and symptomatology of voice disorders, diagnostic procedures and management techniques.
Neuro-anatomy, etiologies, symptomatologies, evaluation procedures and treatment techniques relating to dysarthria in adults.

column2: LANGUAGE ASSESSMENT AND INTERVENTION WITH SCHOOL-AGE POPULATIONS
column6: Theoretical background knowledge and practical assessment and intervention techniques for Department-age children who demonstrate language disorders.

column2: AUTISM SPECTRUM DISORDERS: THEORY AND DIAGNOSIS
column6: Provides an examination of the medical, developmental, social, cognitive, and communicative aspects of disorders on the Autism Spectrum. Assessment and intervention models are explored as they relate to various theoretical models for understanding the presentation of ASD.
Methods of communication and language programming through augmentative and/or alternative modes with a primary focus on interdisciplinary teams and interdisciplinary decision-making and programming.

column2: CLINICAL MANAGEMENT IN SPEECH PATHOLOGY AND AUDIOLOGY
column6: Consideration of problems involved in administration of speech and hearing programs as these vary from hospitals, clinics, Departments and universities.

column2: THE SUPERVISORY PROCESS IN SPEECH PATHOLOGY/AUDIOLOGY
column6: Seeks to emphasize development of process skills related to clinical supervision in speech and hearing.

column2: COMMUNICATION PROGRAMMING FOR CHILDREN WITH MULTIPLE DISABILITIES
column6: Nature and clinical management of the communication disorders of children having a variety of disabling conditions.
Nature and rehabilitative procedures for individuals with congenital and acquired maxillofacial anomalies and resonance disorders.
Consideration of environmental and cultural influences on language behavior and relevance of these factors in programming for language-impaired children.
Anatomy, etiologies, symptomatologies, evaluation procedures and treatment techniques relating to swallowing disorders in adults and children.
Critical review and application of systems and methods for assessment and remediation of articulation and phonological disorders. Repeatable up to 9 hours.
A revolving topics seminar on theoretical and/or clinical issues related to neurogenic/organic speech and/or language disorders.

column2: CLINICAL PRACTICE IN SPEECH PATHOLOGY AND AUDIOLOGY
column6: Supervised clinical practice with patients who have speech, hearing or language problems.
Detailed discussion of current theoretical issues in first language acquisition from the prelinguistic period to the development of complex linguistic and communicative abilities.
Consideration of experimental bases of normal speech production and perception; survey of literature with implications for speech and hearing disorders.

column4: Graduate standing. SPA 64525 PUBLIC SCHOOL TECHNIQUES IN COMMUNICATION DISORDERS:INQUIRY INTO PROFESSIONAL PRACTICE Inquiry into speech pathology and audiology as practiced in the school setting; emphasis on speech language pathologist or audiologist as disciplined investigator. Combination of themes including organizational procedures, therapy techniques, collaboration, ethics and research. Prerequisite: Special approval.
column6: Basic principles of electricity and electronics and their clinical and research applications to speech and hearing.

column2: STUDENT TEACHING IN SPEECH-LANGUAGE PATHOLOGY AND AUDIOLOGY
column6: Inquiry into speech pathology and audiology as practiced in the school setting; emphasis on speech language pathologist or audiologist as disciplined investigator. Combination of themes including organization, procedures, therapy techniques, collaboration, ethics and research. Students are required to complete Bureau of Criminal Investigation and Identification (BCII) and Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) background checks and submit the results to authorized personnel at their assigned "Department/agency" before the first day of the semester in which student teaching/ internship will take place.
Seminar dealing with the theoretical and applied aspects of fluency disorders in children and adults. Repeatable up to 9 hours.

column2: RESEARCH METHODS IN SPEECH-LANGUAGE PATHOLOGY AND AUDIOLOGY
column6: Methodologies for collecting, analyzing and interpreting data for clinical and research purposes in speech language pathology and audiology.

Current literature review and discussions dealing with varying topics ranging from normal aspects of phonation in various populations to disorders of voice and their diagnosis and treatment. Repeatable up to 9 hours.
Consideration of selected topics related to physiological, anatomical and acoustic aspects of speech production and perception. Repeatable up to 9 hours.

column2: SEMINAR: COMMUNICATION MODALITIES AND ASSISTIVE TECHNOLOGY
column4: SPA 64500 and SPA 64302; and graduate standing.
column6: Nature, etiologies and correlates of speech/language communication disorders and differences that may indicate a need for a multi-modal communication approach. Includes an emphasis on assistive technology for communication, language, learning and literacy.

column4: Instructor special approval and speech pathology and audiology (SPA) major only and graduate standing.
column6: Principles and methods of assessment and intervention for various topics in speech-language pathology from critical thinking and case-study framework.

column4: Admission to the AU.D. program or special approval of the instructor and doctoral standing.
column6: Selected current topics in audiology with emphasis on review of current literature.

column4: SPA 70744 and special approval and doctoral standing.
column6: Supervised practicum in audiology requiring the independent performance of basic audiologic procedures, including hearing aid management.

column2: BASIC AND APPLIED PHYSICAL ACOUSTICS FOR AUDIOLOGY
column4: Admission to the AU.D. program or special approval of instructor and doctoral standing.
column6: Study of physical acoustics, basic electricity and electronics, as well as principles, methodology, calibration and maintenance of audiologic equipment.

column2: ANATOMY AND PHYSIOLOGY OF PERIPHERAL AUDITORY AND VESTIBULAR SYSTEMS
column4: Admission to the Au.D program or special approval of instructor and doctoral standing.
column6: A study of the anatomy, biophysics and physiology of the auditory and vestibular systems.

column4: Admission to the AU.D. program and doctoral standing.
column6: Study of the acoustics, measurement and nomenclature of speech sounds and theoretical and acoustic bases of speech perception (includes 1 hour lab).

column2: CRITICAL ANALYSIS OF RESEARCH IN AUDIOLOGY
column4: Admission to the AU.D. program and doctoral standing.
column6: General introduction to the research process with an emphasis on acquiring a reading knowledge of research and an ability to evaluate research.

column4: Admission to the AU.D. program and doctoral standing.
column6: Study of conditions/diseases that can affect the auditory system.
An in-depth study of the anatomy and physiology of the central auditory and vestibular nervous system (includes 1 hour lab.)

column4: Admission to the AU.D. program and doctoral standing.
column6: Study of the principles, procedures and research of psychoacoustics; the relationships between the physical dimensions of auditory stimuli and the resultant perceptual experience with normal and impaired hearing.
Development of a reading knowledge of research and the ability to evaluate the quality of research studies.

column4: Admission to the Au.D. program and doctoral standing.
column6: Theoretical basis for tests underlying basic audiologic assessments.

column4: Admission to the AU.D. program and doctoral standing.
column6: Theoretical principles of noise measurement; etiology of noise-induced hearing loss and acoustic trauma; industrial hearing conservation programs; occupational safety and health act; community and recreational noise evaluation and management.

column4: Admission to the AU.D. program and doctoral standing.
column6: Examination of normal and abnormal aspects of speech and language including their impact on auditory function and testing.
Underlying theory and principles of administration and interpretation of site-of-lesion tests.
Study of amplification systems for the hearing impaired.

column4: Admission to the AU.D. program and doctoral standing.
column6: Physiological, psychological and sociological theories of aging with a focus on the etiology, symptomatology, assessment and rehabilitation of older adults with hearing impairments.

column4: SPA 70705 and SPA 70706 and doctoral standing.
column6: Study of audiologic evaluation and habilitation/rehabilitation procedures for people having central auditory disabilities.
Examination of the theory and practice of fitting hearing aids. Emphasis on special clinical procedures research needs and evolving technology in hearing instruments. Includes a one hour lab.
Study of audiologic diagnostic and auditory habilitative protocols for the birth to 3 population. Both assessment and management strategies will be emphasized.

column4: Admission to the AU.D. program and doctoral standing.
column6: Study of cochlear implants in children and adults including equipment, candidacy, mapping and overview of (re)habilitation.

column4: Admission to the AU.D. program and doctoral standing.
column6: Focus on interviewing, counseling and interacting with individuals with hearing impairments their families and significant others.

column4: SPA 70713 and SPA 70716 and SPA 70717 and doctoral standing.
column6: The focus of study is on amplification systems and fitting techniques for the pediatric population.

column2: EVALUATION AND MANAGEMENT OF BALANCE DISORDERS
column4: Admission to the AU.D. program or special approval of instructor and doctoral standing.
column6: Study of the balance mechanism; differential diagnostic assessment of balance disorders including electronystagmography, posturography and rotational testing; rehabilitation of the balance disordered patient (1 hour lab included.)

column2: AUDIOLOGIC MANAGEMENT OF THE SCHOOL-AGE CHILD
column6: Focus on educational audiology. Features delivery of audiologic services designed to access the school environment for children ages 4-21.

column4: SPA 70716 or special approval of instructor and doctoral standing.
column6: Study of current methodologies employed in the audiologic rehabilitation of adults with hearing impairments. Implementation of remedial strategies is emphasized.

column4: Admission to the AU.D. program and doctoral standing.
column6: An examination of the history of deafness/hearing impairment and the profession of audiology.
A study of the multidisciplinary approach to medical/surgical management of patients with auditory and vestibular disorders.
Study of evoked responses used in diagnostic audiology, including ABR, MLR,ECHOCHG, ENOG, ALR, P300, VER, and SSER.

column4: Admission to the AU.D. program and doctoral standing.
column6: An introduction to deaf culture and the audiologist's roles and responsibilities in planning treatment with a member of the deaf community.

column4: Admission to the AU.D. program and doctoral standing.
column6: Study of issues which impact the management of audiological practices, including establishing a private practice, reimbursement, marketing, record keeping and professional liability.

column4: Admission to the AU.D. program or special approval of the instructor and doctoral standing.
column6: Introduction to clinical practicum in audiology. Directed observation of clinical practice including audiologic diagnosis and audiologic rehabilitation are required.

column4: Admission to the Au.D. program and doctoral standing and special approval.
column6: Introduction to clinical practicum in audiology. Directed observation of clinical practice including audiologic diagnosis and audiologic rehabilitation are required.

column5: SPA 70709 and special approval of instructor and doctoral standing.
column6: Clinical practicum in audiology during which students perform discrete tasks under supervision. Corequisite: SPA 70709 and special approval of instructor and doctoral standing.

column4: SPA 70743 and special approval and doctoral standing.
column6: Supervised clinical practicum in audiology during which students will perform discrete clinical tasks while under supervision.
Supervised clinical practicum in audiology which encompasses audiologic assessments and audiologic habilitation.

column4: SPA 70747 and doctoral standing and special approval.
column6: Supervised clinical practicum in audiology requiring the independent performance of audiologic assessment procedures, audiologic rehabilitation and vestibular assessment and rehabilitation.

Full-time clinical practicum in audiology at an off-campus site. SPA 70748 and passing score of 600 or higher on the PRAXIS examination and doctoral standing and special approval. Corequisite: SPA 70791.
Full-time clinical practicum in audiology at an off-campus site. Students taking the course must have successfully completed the Praxis Examination.
Full-time clinical practicum in audiology at an off-campus site.

column5: SPA 70750 or SPA 70751 or special approval of instructor and doctoral standing.
column6: In-depth consideration of topics/issues in the practice of audiology with emphasis upon issues related to clinical rotation. Course is repeatable. Corequisite: SPA 70750 or SPA 70751 or special approval of instructor and doctoral standing.

Supervised clinical practicum in audiology requiring the independent performance of diagnostic, hearing aids and audiologic rehabilitation procedures. Students are required to complete Bureau of Criminal Investigation and Identification (BCII) and Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) background checks and submit the results to authorized personnel at their assigned "Department/agency" before the first day of the semester in which student teaching/internship will take place.

column4: Admission to the AU.D.. program and doctoral standing.
column6: Completion of a doctoral research project including data collection, analysis write- up and oral presentation.
